document.text: With membership reports indica ting a nice attendance, the Young Democratic Club of Appomattox co unty is all set for its second annual Brunswick Stew, to be held at 4 P. M. tomorrow, Friday, August 23, at Holiday Lake. Senator William, M. Tuck, of Halifax, a prospective candidate for Governor next year, will be speaker. A number of prominent Democrats from neighboring counties have been invited to attend. An expert in the art of making 1 Brunswick Stew, from Charlotte co-  unty, has been engaged and will be on the job early tomorrow morning. President Watt Abbitt said he ex pected to have a membership this year of between 150 and 200.irhe annual dues of the club are 1.00, and entitle one to attend the Bruns wick Stew without extra charge. Tickets may be secured from any member of a large membership com mittee, and will be available at the lake tomorrow afternoon. The Young Democratic Clubs are composed of younger members of the party and serve as a traing ground for future leaders. The organiza tion was highly honored Tuesday in R.chmond, when one of iis number, Horace Edwards, of Richmond, was chosen chairman of the State Senior Democratic Committee, to succeed the late Murray Hooker. The Sta.e Young Democratic con vention will be held in Richmond on September 6 and 7. A regular meet ing of the local club will be held tomorrow after the speaking. Funeral oí Mrs. arson

document.text: Virginia National Bank has made a donation of 10,000 toward construction of the new Holiday Lake 4-H Continuing Educational Cen ter in Appomattox. In expressing apprecia tion for Virginia Nationals contribution. Coach Jimmie B. Bryan, general campaign chairman, said, We are very grateful for the support given to the Holiday Lake Center by corporations such as Virginia National. This center will fill a great need for a year-round facility by the people of Central Virginia, and the interest being displayed by busi nesses and individuals is both encouraging and heart ening. The Holiday Lake Camp opened in Appomattox in 1941 under the direction of the Virginia Extension Ser vice and the 4-H Club as a summer camp for 4-H members. By the 1970s, it was serving more than 1,000 children a year, as well as accommodating special tr aining sessions, schools and retreats for. adults. The expanded new facility

document.text: Twelve families were repres- sented at the annual family Holiday Lake for 4- Hers Sunday The dinner was by the program of reports on the high-lights of the year. Sam Jones told of the National 4-H Conference at the National 4-H Camp in Washing ton, D. C. on Connecticut Avenue last spring. He was one of six to represent the state of Virginia. Each state having had an equal number of delegates. Glenn Giles was a Virginia delegate to the Agricultural Institute of Corporatives at the State Agriculture College in Ames, Iowa, in July. The institutes main interest was Our National Economy. James Hancock, 111 told of hia experiences at Conserva tion Camp at Camp Farrar, at Virginia Beach this summer. Ann Evans, Debbie Calohan, Terry Coffey, Sam Jones, and James Hancock 111 gave bits of interests learned and things shared at State 4-H Congress at VPI last June. Sylvia Carson modeling a dress she made, told about the Area Contest for Junior 4-Hers last spring. Debbie Calohan explained the job of a Junior Leader at the Jr. 4-H Camp. She was a Jr. leader at our Smith Mt. Lake Camp this time. We also had junior members at Jr. Camp at Holiday Lake. The Senior 4-H Camp was attended by Debbie Calohan and Ann Evans. Gayle Carson and Ann Evans attended Virginia State Horsemanship Workshop in Richmond, July 10 for six days and Ann Evans stayed for two days longer for extra training and contests offered. The Charles F. Jones family were guests of the club and Yolanda Paasch came as a new member for Sherwill. A nominating committee was named by the president, Terry Coffey. document.text: Tussday was Democratic Day in Appomattox and Buckingham, as a throng of 800 attended the first annual Young Democratic barbecue and rally at beautiful Holiday Lake. A galaxy of political leaders from all sachons of the Old Dominion attended the event, hailed as the largest political rally in this section in the past dacade. After enjoying the musical enter tainment of the crack 45-piece Am erican Legion drum and bugle corps from Lynchburg, the crowd gather ed before a speakers stand nestling in a grove near the 147i-area lake, to hear addresses from many of the distinguished guests. W. M. Ab- bitt, president of the Appomattox Young Democratic Club, presided. Calvin H. Robinson, fourth district chairman, presented visiting Young Democratic leaders. Senator Moses introduced other party leaders pre sent. J. P. Andrews, ip charge of j the federal development in the lake i area, drew applause when he an- ! nounced that a wire received that 1 morning brought news that funds had been made available to finish work on the project. Senator William M. Tuck, of Halifax was presented for a few re marks, following which Harry Griffin of Buckingham introduced Congress man A. Willis Robertson, of Lexing- tqn. Mr. Robertson lauded the Dem ocracy of the Fourth District, and praised the progress in conservation work made by the present national administration. Judge Thomas W. Ozlin was pre sented by Delegate John B. Boat wright. Speaking on the theme of True Liberalism, Mr. Ozlin,. who is a member of the State Corpora tion Commission, launched an at tack on loose financial policies, and urged Virginia Democracy to rally around the leadership of those seek ing to guide from within the party its policies toward liberalism, with out recklessness. Mr. Ozlin declared that many of the current divisions in the Demo- acratic party involved what is and whac fa pot liberalism. He said that true liberals were those who have attempted to uphold the Con stitution of the United States and the financial soundness of the na tion. He attacked any past or fu ture attempts to purge from the party those who were, in reality, its true liberals, in favor of radicals, and political crack-pots.

document.text: This Saturday afternoon at 180 at toe court house members of the Young Democratic Club of Appo mattox county will meet o arrange this years membership drive and set up plans to promote the cause of toe party during the Presidential year. President Witokfeia M. Ab- bitt urges all Young Democrats to attend this meeting and to bring suggestions for toe welfare of the club. Last year the Appomattox Young Democrats had 489 members to rank as one of toe largest in toe state. Chief feature of 1939 activities was a gala barscue and public speaking at Holiday Lake. This event was a t tended by Senator Harry Flood Byrd and a galexy of state political lead ers and attracted attention as one of the finest accomplishments of any Young Democratic Cltib in Vir ginia. The annual Young Democratic State Convention will be held the first week-end in September in Rich mond. In these conventions dubs have one vote for each ten paid-up _ members This year Hon. document.text: Thirty six Appomattox 4-IT- ers took part in the Area Junior 4-H Contest at Brookville High School. Twenty-two of these 4-Hers were first place winners With an additional nine 4-Hers being second place winners. Were especially proud of each of the 4-Hers who took part. Many parents and teenagers also assisted with the program which involved 4-Hers from Amherst, Halifax, Campbell and Bedford as well as Appomattox. The real strength of such a program is shown by parental participation. We were glad to see many parents of Appomat tox 4-Hers involved in the program Saturday.    The East Central District 4-H Horse and Pony Schooling Clinic will be conducted in two sessions this summer. The first portion Hunter Division will be at the Wintergreen Riding Center on July 8. document.text: The sixteenth annual Boys For estry Campi wus held during the week of June 26 through Julyl. State Forester George W. Dean stated that 92 boy attended camp this year and will curry buck to their community a wealth of know ledge learned from the forestry courses taught at camp. The camp is held each year At Holiday Lake located on the Buck ingham Appomattox State Forest. One hundred scholarships were a- warded to Virginia boys between the ages of 14-18 years judged thç post deserving from the stand point of activity and interest shown In sound forest conservation meth ods. At the end of the camp week the boys were carefully1 tested on the subjects taught during the camp period. The instructors and counsellor selected as best campers three outstanding boys who dis played the most leadership, init iative, interest and who also made good grades on their test papers. Trained professional foresters from the pulp and paper industry and the Virginia Division of For estry and a wildlife technician from the Commission of Game and Inland Fisheries handled the instruction at camp. Courses taught included forest fire control, crusising, mark ing and management and timber harvesting processing.

document.text: The Holiday Lake 4-H Education al Center is participating in the Special Milk Program. Milk will be provided to all children without charge. Acceptance and participation in this program and all activities are the same for all regardless of race, color, national origin, sex or handicap, and there will be no discrimination in the course of the meal. Milk will be provided at Holiday Lake 4-H Center from June 13 1983.

document.text: The concessionaire of Holi day Lake Recreation Area has announced that all facilities will be open to the public this week end, next week end will open on a full-time basis on Sat., May 27. John Porter Glenn said that camping, picnicing, swimming, boating and fishing facilities will be available this week end, weather permitting. Swimming classes will be offered this sea son, he says, and new features at Holiday Lake include canoes and a new type of paddle boat. Also, sail boats.

document.text: The Class of 62 of Appo mattox High School held its Tenth Reunion Saturday, August 12, at the 4-H Camp at Holiday Lake. Class members and their families spent the I afternoon swimming, playing  different sports, but most of all I reminising and catching up on the last ten years. Former teachers were dis cussed school trips ball games and tournaments the Class of 62 starting the first school newspaper the Senior Class Play. Old snapshots that hap pened to appear made these memories even more vivid. Class President, B a r r y Beale, called the gathering to order for a short meeting. After reading the original class prophecy and a short quiz on such trivia as class flower, motto, etc., the roll call showed thirty-six 36 members pre sent - out of a graduating of seventy-one 71. One class member, Jean Brown Ogg, had passed away since graduation and her class mates voted to give a book to the Appomattox County Library in her mem ory. The class also voted to write the School Board agreeing with the suggestion to name the new high school for the late Earl Smith. Several prizes were awarded to recognize special class members. Among t h o s e awards given were to Nancy Chandler Roberts for traveling the farthest over 800 miles

document.text: The Appomattox Teen Leader Club sponsored an Interstate Exchange Program with eleven 4-H members and two adults from Adams County, Nebraska from July 1 through July 16th. Eight families. in Appomattox County hosted these 4-Hers in their homes for the ten day stay. The 4-Her lived with the family and was involved in all family activities. Usually a trip or tour was planned for the entire group each day. A picnic at the J. M. Cobb home was held on the second night of their visit. This sparked many friendships which proved to make it a fun filled week. While in Appomattox, they visited such sites as the Appomattox-Buckinghain State Forest, Holiday Lake and the Holiday Lake 4-H

document.text: The Appomattox Sub-district M.Y.F. Spiritual Life Adventure will begin on Saturday, June 27, at 1 p.m. and continue through Sunday, June 28, 1 p.m. on the 4-H side of Holiday Lake. The theme for the week end will be Seek and Ye Shall Find. Camp director will be Rev. W. L. Ayres and camp nurse will be Mrs. ANN Ayres. There will be three discovery groups .1 God Communicates with Man, led by Dr. Edgar A. Potts, District Supt. 2 Man communicates with God, led by Rev. W. L. Ayres, pastor of the Appomattox Methodist Circuit. 3 Man communicates with man, led by Mr. David Martin, counselor for the Trinity M.YF. On Saturday afternoon, the group will go swimming, play softball, horse shoes, volley ball, and other outdoor games. That night, group recreation will be led by Mrs. Lillian Marita. The Rev. Forrest Wagoner will con duct a Lakeside Vesper Service following the evening meal. A movie Deeper Roots, the story of a real senior high group telling their own unrehearsed feelings and thoughts, and sink ing their roots of life deeper in the Christian Faith, will be shown. Sunday morning worship services will be led by Dr. Edgar A. Potts.
